Karen Evans — Launch Prof
Founder of The Launch Professor. Also attorney, speaker, professor, improviser and mother.
Sep 12, 2016

Why “Startups” Aren’t Everything

The recent focus on Silicon Valley “unicorns” is fascinating to watch. Tech companies are being built and sold, re-branded and reformulated, and selling themselves to other tech companies for millions or billions of dollars. Cities around the world are trying to position themselves as the “next” Silicon Valley, seeking to bring the notoriety of the next Facebook or the next Tesla to their shores.

Meanwhile, on what seems like the other end of the spectrum, the United States Small Business Administration defines a “small business” based on employment or income numbers that seem large to the average entrepreneur. For instance, if you are a lawyer with your own firm, you will be considered a “small business” when you start bringing in $11 million.

It’s enough to make the entrepreneur who is plugging away building websites for other local businesses, photographing family portraits, or writing for regional blog feel a little . . . depressed. It’s also enough to make the freelancer shake her head and say, “I’ll never be able to leave my full time job — there’s no way I have what it takes to be an entrepreneur.”

The splashy tech stories make for great news, and the talk of millions of dollars is captivating, to be sure. But it’s the one or two-person businesses — the micropreneurs that are helping to spur local economies and help families in ways that many aren’t paying attention to. On the individual scale, a single mom bringing in the $50,000 a year her family needs, originating out of her graphic design work, isn’t newsworthy, but it’s everything to her family. A paper from FIELD at the Aspen Institute, which studies microenterprises, mentions: “ The income gained [from a microenterprise] is an important component of household income and can lift families out of poverty.”

“ The income gained [from a microenterprise] is an important component of household income and can lift families out of poverty.”

In 2012, according to the Census Bureau, “very small enterprises” (businesses employing 20 or fewer employees) were the second-largest employer, after “large enterprises” (businesses employing more than 500 employees). They were ahead of “medium” and “small” enterprises. In 2011, there were 2.8 million businesses employing 1–4 people. That’s a lot of businesses to be leaving out of national and local conversation about attracting and helping “small” businesses.

The problem with missing out on the microenterprises is that we are creating legislation to incentivize growth among the gazelles without paying attention to the main street businesses. Microenterprises have less access to traditional bank loans and other capital than do “small” enterprises, and face other significant hurdles (in fact, researchers have suggested that the lack of resources available to microenterprises is a worse problem than is unemployment. Since many micropreneurs pursue self-employment after becoming unemployed, it’s a double whammy to realize the marketplace isn’t set up to help you succeed). And yet, according to a paper from the Women’s Initiative for Self Employment, “[c]omparisons of the economic impact of independent businesses and national chains have demonstrated that independent businesses contribute more (in relation to both sales and square footage) to the local economy because they tend to purchase more local goods and services and create more local jobs.”

[I]ndependent businesses contribute more (in relation to both sales and square footage) to the local economy

If you are a micropreneur, or thinking of becoming one, don’t look wistfully at the unicorns and say “I can’t ever do that, so I don’t know why I bother.” Your work matters. Your talent matters. Even if it’s only to you, or to your family, or to the two people you employ — when you aggregate that with the hard work of all the other micropreneurs out there, the economic impact is significant.

So what should you, the micropreneur, do? At the high level, you can advocate for policy changes that would make the world a little more friendly to the millions of microbusinesses that exist. In the immediate time frame, though, take time to connect with the resources that are available, both economically and socially. For instance, lending platforms such as Kiva are created for micropreneurs and, contrary to common belief, are open to entrepreneurs globally (including in both developing and developed countries). Many communities are starting to look at other community investment models where businesses seek investment from smaller, local investors. For instance, Sidewalk Ventures in Detroit recently helped Detroit City FC, a soccer team, raise $725,000 — with investors receiving $100,000 in the first payout.

Research suggests that a strong social network can maximize the success of a micropreneur. If you don’t feel comfortable at the traditional “good old boys” networking events, find or create ways to make meaningful social connections within your own local community. Or, take to the Internet and reach out to communities of people in your own industry — people who have been there, done that and are willing to share their ideas; people who are open to brainstorming about new ways to do things; people who are there to commiserate with and be inspired by.

Micropreneurs are important players in the global economy, and the income from a microenterprise can make all the difference in the world for a single household. Micropreneurs can empower themselves to achieve even more success by taking advantage of available resources and building strong social networks. Unicorns are fun to watch, but they can go back to being a myth in a single bad day on the stock market; a microenterprise with a solid business model and a confident leader can be built to last generations. You can build your own future.
